name: Tenoch
desc: A hero of Natlan, who lived 500 years ago. He didn't belong to any tribe, because he was exiled. During the Cataclysm, he united the six tribes and went to the western islands to fight a giant black monster.

customize.text: Tenoch

About two thousand years ago, the first Pyro Archon, Xbalanque, appeared in Natlan. He was wise and powerful — he loved his people and was beloved by them. After the Archon's death, his best friend, Och-Kan, began to rule the nation. Trying to lead his people to prosperity, he opened the door to malevolent forces, and his soul was corrupted by the Abyss. A civil war broke out in Natlan, in which Och-Kan was overthrown, and his people, who wielded the power of Anemo, were exiled. Some of the exiles chose to accept their exile, abandoned their homeland forever, and headed to the true land of wind, where they received a new name, the "Muratans." The other group refused to leave until they were allowed to settle down elsewhere, albeit in the most barren and remote part of their nation, on Tenochtzitoc. They lived in neglect for millennia until darkness returned once more. The kingdom was still divided, and these exiles were the first to raise their weapons. Although they were destitute, not a single one of them retreated or fled. With the same stubborn spirit that bade them never abandon their homeland all those years ago, they fought and died until, at last, only one remained — Tenoch.

Before the Cataclysm five hundred years ago, Tenoch was banished from his tribe and stripped of his Ancient Name for his constant disputes and fighting. But when the black tide spread across Natlan, he took his obsidian club and traveled to other tribes to unite the bickering tribes. The first to join Tenoch was the great runner Wanjiru of the Collective of Plenty, along with her companion, Kayeke. Although the constant infighting among the major tribes was exhausting, Tenoch's invitation had reignited her vigor, and the Collective of Plenty agreed to fight for the lands of Natlan. The second to join Tenoch was the brave Menilek from the Flower-Feather Clan and the Qucusaurus, Ngoubou. Although the tribes often feuded with Tenoch, he was a hero to Menilek. The third to join Tenoch was the Border Master of the Masters of the Night-Wind, Sanhaj Kompore, and the Iktomisaurus, Mahamba. Although Sanhaj had already foreseen his and Tenoch's heroic end, and how the place that would become known as the "Mare Jivari" in later days would be born, he followed him anyway. The fourth to voluntarily join Tenoch was the young Burkina of the Scions of the Canopy and the Yumkasaurus, Kongamato. War had left countless scars upon Tenoch's body, and for Burkina, these were the proof of the path that he, too, must tread.

The fifth to be convinced by Tenoch were the head of the Children of Echoes mines, Sundjatta, and the Stegosaurus, Muhuru. It was Sundjatta who had once petitioned the Pyro Archon to vote for Tenoch's expulsion in order to avoid further conflicts. But realizing that this could be the last battle of their generation, Sundjatta joined, asking not to involve his tribe. The sixth to join Tenoch was his greatest foe in his youth, the giant Tupac of the People of the Springs. During their battles, Tupac was left with over three hundred scars, twenty broken bones, and over one hundred obsidian shards lodged deep within his body. And the giant himself left the hero with two hundred minor wounds, two broken ribs, and an eye that could no longer perceive distance. The two former enemies burst into riotous laughter, and they joined hands, and thus, Tenoch found allies from the six largest tribes, becoming the leaders of the united army of Natlan. All six heroes bore the Ancient Names of the companions of the first Pyro Archon, Xbalanque, and five hundred years later, they became the key to the destruction of the Abyss in Natlan.

During the war with the Abyss, the Natlanese calculations estimated that they would have a maximum of five hundred years before the Night Kingdom was completely lost to the Abyss, but at that time, Natlan lay in ruins, and the civilization was dying. It was necessary to unite the tribes, otherwise, it would be impossible to dream of a final victory. So, the Archon had a long and involved discussion with the heroes of each tribe, and finally came up with a five-hundred-year-long plan to save Natlan. During this time, the Archons and chiefs were to rebuild the tribes, and when the time came, the Wayob would again choose six heroes of Natlan with the Ancient Names of Xbalanque's companions. Haborym placed her life within the Sacred Flame in order to be reborn in five hundred years and carry out her plan. Although Tenoch believed that his rage would never know absolution, and his power would no longer aid her victory, he accepted the Archon's choice.

<color=#ffffffd9>"I understand your choice.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>The heroes of today will forge the path ahead with blood and fire.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Just remember to earn us the victory we're owed.</color>
<color=#ffffffd9>Otherwise, rest assured, I'll find a way to collect the debt."</color>

As Sanhaj Kompore had foreseen, Tenoch's final battle was the one that marked the birth of the Mare Jivari. Of all the Abyssal monsters that had attacked Natlan five hundred years ago, the most terrifying was Bakunawa, the creation of the Khaenri'ahn alchemist, Rhinedottir. It was Bakunawa who had wiped out every tribe on Tenochtzitoc until only Tenoch remained. The monster was impossible to kill: even when it was beheaded or had its body chopped into pieces, the remains would somehow continue to grow, seeking each other out and eventually, forming a new, revitalized Bakunawa. Realizing that Bakunawa could consume all of Natlan, Tenoch chose to sacrifice himself. He let Sanhaj perform Phlogiston Engraving on his body in order to unleash the power of border spells to expand the boundaries of the Night Kingdom and manifest a portion of it in the real world. Then, Tenoch allowed himself to be eaten by Bakunawa. With Tenoch's body as the ritual offering, Sanhaj summoned a miniature Night Kingdom inside Bakunawa's belly, and the clash between the powers of the Abyss, the Lord of the Night, and Tenoch's spirit in Bakunawa's body led to a violent explosion that shattered the monster into innumerable pieces. The explosion created the Mare Jivari, and the leader of the united army of the Natlan tribes and the Border Master perished.

Tenoch received the honorary hero name Tenoyollotzin, which means "the honored heart of Tenochtzitoc," and was buried in his homeland. Although Tenoch's sacrifice did not destroy Bakunawa entirely, it allowed Natlan to defeat and implement the Pyro Archon's plan five hundred years later. To keep Bakunawa from being reborn, the Pyro Archons built a hall in the space beyond Natlan that led to the Mare Jivari. There, they set up the thrones of Tenoch and the six heroes of Natlan, where they placed their weapons, and Haborym took Tenoch’s Talking Stick. On Tenoch's throne, which opens the portal to the Mare Jivari, is engraved, <color=#ffffffd9>"To the everlasting Tenoch. His remains are buried here."</color>

customize.desc: In order to pursue the great dream in the morning mist and sea of clouds, the warriors who soared the skies never rested for a moment.

customize.name: Mare Jivari
